Subject: [TRUB] Re: Oatmeal Stout
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain

Regarding the oatmeal stout, both Bill's and Keith's suggestions seem to be on
the money.

An additional datapoint - the BJCP style committee is generally of the opinion
that the bitterness of an oatmeal stout should fall in between a sweet stout
(very low, like low 20s for IBUs) and a dry stout (as Keith indicated up around
40 IBUs).  Bitterness should be present, and a clear part of the flavor profile,
but not so much as detract from the appreciation of the "oily silkiness" of the
oats.  I'd shoot for a balanced profile, with not much in the way of finishing
hops (if any at all).

Save me a bottle,
Craig

Dedpetvet@AOL.COM wrote:

> One of the problems with making oatmeal stouts is the high level of gums in
> the oatmeal.  These gummy stuff will stick up your mash and give you several
> heaaches and loooooong lauder times.  There are two ways around this.  One is
> to include a large handful of rice hulls in the mash or add extra grain and
> grind it faurly coursely.  The other is to include a beta-gluconase rest at
> 120 degrees F. for 30 minutes This will break these gums into shaller pieces.
> BUT, you might loose the "silky" mouth feel that is characteristic of this
> style beer.  If you do neither then be prepaired to cut the filter bed
> extensively during the lauder.  If you don't have flaked barley you can
> substitute breakfast "mother's oats"  either Standard or instant.  If you have
> never constructed a grain bill from a reciepe expressed in % before, the %
> represent the contribution of sugar to the final wort.  It DOESN'T represent
> the weight of the grain.
>
> Bill MacK
